Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Award: Community Growth and Sustainability in Unstable Times

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to better understand the development of geopolitical centers in the Maya Lowlands during the Terminal Classic period, a time of general decline and abandonment across the Maya region. Researchers have previously identified a handful of centers that developed during this time, but the mechanisms for economic and political growth during a period of social upheaval, increasing conflict, and recurrent droughts remain poorly studied. To address these issues doctoral student Rafael. Guerra under the direction of Dr. Keith Prufer, will conduct archaeology fieldwork at the Maya city-state of Lower Dover located in the Belize River Valley, Belize Central America. In this region, most large Maya centers developed over many centuries following their initial foundation and are geographically evenly spaced at ~10 km apart. Preliminary research at Lower Dover suggests it developed rapidly between two of these long-established centers and at a time when neighboring sites were declining and engaged in significant interpolity conflict described in hieroglyphic texts. While Lower Dover lacks a hieroglyphic record, it may be an example of an economic "boom town" which flourished economically and politically in the power vacuum created by the abandonment of well-established Belize Valley polities. The success of Lower Dover at that time may be linked to its strategic location, along the Belize River giving it direct access to important long-distance trade routes and the ability to act as gateway between the upper and lower Belize River valley. It remains that by the end of the Terminal Classic Period (ca. AD 950) Lower Dover too was abandoned. In a region where the growth of major centers occurred over long periods of time, this research has potential to inform on the changes in political, social and economic structures during an interval of massive upheaval. The resulting dissertation will contribute to understanding of how the declining fortunes of some polities can foster opportunities for others, and to explore the stability of these "boom town" economies. The results of this research will be of interest to social scientists studying the resilience of complex geopolitical systems, and will contribute to the development of a promising young scholar.

Fieldwork at Lower Dover consists of excavations and geochemical testing of soils and will focus on investigating a possible marketplace and riverside docking facility identified in preliminary studies by the co-PI., as well as investigations in the site core and settlements to develop a high-resolution chronology for the development and decline of the community. This precise AMS 14C chronology will allow determination of whether there was an existing local population prior to the development of the monumental core, or if the founders colonized previously unoccupied space between two declining polities. Preparations of radiocarbon samples with be undertaken by the co-PI at the University of New Mexico Center for Stable Isotopes. Detailed ceramic studies and analysis by pXRF of obsidian will illustrate economic interactions between Lower Dover and potential regional and long distance trade networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The establishment of large, urban centers and the social, economic, and demographic factors that impact their growth and decline are central themes for anthropological archaeologists who study complex societies. Research in the development of ancient cities has the potential to inform on strategies utilized in the transformation of settlements into larger urban centers with fully developed political systems.  It can also inform on rapid developments during times of hardship. This project focused on the development of the ancient Maya city of Lower Dover in Belize Central America. Preliminary data indicates that the site was develop during a time of upheaval and climate instability in the region. The project focused on the foundation, development and eventual decline of the center. It is very likely that Lower Dover developed out of a need to provide access to the supporting population to a major trade network, the Belize River, by reducing the transport distance and providing a space for the exchange of goods (market).

This project conducted extensive fieldwork for gather archaeological information and multiple methods (radiocarbon dating techniques, statistical analyses, ceramic and lithic artifact analyses, and soil chemistry analyses) to determine the exact timing of developments, local versus non local influences on polity development and possible accommodations made by the elites to accommodate their local supporting populations. Surrounding settlements and large centers in the region were occupied much earlier than Lower Dover and as such it was necessary to map the development of the supporting settlement area for the site.  This allowed the Co-PI to record the tempo of occupation in the site’s catchment area.   Excavations in the sites central urban area and surrounding households provided organic materials used for the radiocarbon dating.  Spatial data on the locations of households, combined with excavation data was used to identify the tempo of development at the site. Ceramic and lithic artifacts were analyzed to map the interaction of Lower Dover with other sites both locally and non-locally.  Soil chemistry data were used to investigate a possible market at one of the largest open spaces in the central urban area of the site.

Overall, the project provided substantive educational opportunities to over 60+ undergraduate students in the US at various opportunities as well as several Belizean students and laborers. During the project (3 years) the Co-PI was responsible for supervising excavations and laboratory processing and artifact analyses.

The data collected to date and the analyses of this project demonstrate that Lower Dover developed rapidly during a time of political and climate instability. The chronology of the site indicates that some households, with four or more structures were established by at least the Late Pre-Classic period (300 B.C. – A.D. 300)  However, the central precinct and related households of one or two structures were rapidly built in the Late Classic period ( A.D. 600 – 850) and were occupied until abandonment and general depopulation of the city in the Terminal Classic period (A.D. 850 – 950). Many of the large urban areas were settled and occupied by the Middle Pre-Classic and continued occupied until the Late Classic Period.  This indicates that the Lower Dover site can be considered an ‘instant city’ city that rapidly developed in the Late Classic period. Earlier occupation in several large households withing the supporting population indicates the possibility that Lower Dover developed in the vacuum of a previous polity that disintegrated prior to 600 A.D. This would indicate that political and economic elites at Lower Dover were able to coerce the population to invest labor in the construction of the urban center during this time of instability. This Project provides data on how and why urban centers may develop and the compromises and accommodations that leaders may take during times of uncertainty.
